topics.title: Brainstorming Is Broken: Why Groups Kill Ideas

hook.text: Alex Osborn invented brainstorming in 1953, promising it would double creative output.

buildup.text: Groups brainstorming together produce fewer AND lower-quality ideas than the same number of people working.

discovery.text: Three killers: production blocking (waiting your turn), evaluation apprehension (fear of judgment), and social loafing.

twist.text: The fix: 'brainwriting.' Everyone writes ideas silently, then shares them.

climax.text: Amazon's Jeff Bezos banned brainstorming meetings. Instead, everyone writes a six-page memo read silently.

punchline.text: Brainstorming feels creative. Working alone actually IS creative.

quiz.question: Why does traditional brainstorming produce fewer ideas than individual work?
options: Production blocking, evaluation apprehension, and social loafing

topics.title: Money Motivates Creativity: When Rewards Backfire

hook.text: Offer a child money for drawing, and they'll draw more. Remove the money, and they'll draw LESS than before you started.

topics.title: Technology Kills Creativity: The Luddite Fallacy

hook.text: Socrates feared writing would destroy memory. Critics said photography would kill painting.

topics.title: Multitasking Kills Creativity: Mostly True, With One Exception

hook.text: Multitasking reduces cognitive performance by 40%. Except for one type: working on MULTIPLE creative projects.

buildup.text: Rapid task-switching (email + writing + calls) devastates deep creative work.

discovery.text: But working on 2-3 creative projects in PARALLEL (not simultaneously) helps.

twist.text: Darwin worked on multiple books at once. Einstein juggled physics problems.
